docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Russia Agrees to a Plan To Curb Plutonium Threat Russia has promised to stop making plutonium out of fuel from its civilian power reactors as part of a $100 million joint research and aid package from the United States, administration and Russian officials said. docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton on Monday will submit a $1.84 trillion federal budget for next year and will call for using much of the projected budget surplus over the next decade to strengthen and expand the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly, administration officials said today. Mr. Clinton's plan calls for spending on government programs outside of Social Security and Medicare, the third of the total budget that Congress revisits each year, to grow 3.9 percent next year, and at slightly less than the rate of inflation over the next decade. The administration projects that inflation will be about 2.6 percent a year over the period.

headline.main: CLINTON, IN BUDGET, SEEKS TO BOLSTER MEDICARE PROGRAM

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will submit $1.84 trillion federal budget for next fiscal year, which calls for using much of projected surplus over next decade to strengthen and expand Medicare system of health insurance for elderly; budget calls for 3.9 percent growth in fiscal 2001 on spending on government programs outside of Social Security and Medicare and for spending on such programs to grow less than projected rate of inflation of 2.6 percent over next decade; $432 billion of administration's projection of $746 billion surplus would go to Medicare over next decade; Clinton plan would use surplus to give poor children and their families better access to health insurance, to pay for modest tax cuts and for programs like aid to farmers; proposes $350 billion in tax cuts over decade, offset in part by $100 billion in revenues from closing corporate tax loopholes; other budget proposals noted; Republicans criticize budget as bloated and developed with eye more toward fall 2000 elections than toward getting legislation enacted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton on Monday will submit a $1.84 trillion federal budget for next year and will call for using much of the projected budget surplus over the next decade to strengthen and expand the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Bradley said flatly today that he must win primaries in several states on the next big day of voting, March 7. And to do so, he said, he must sell his agenda more powerfully to hard-core Democrats who streamed to Vice President Al Gore in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary. Even as he expressed optimism about his prospects for the presidential nomination, Mr. Bradley seemed to concede what many prominent Democrats, including his own supporters, said in interviews. That is, that the race will be effectively over in four weeks if he does not emerge with significant victories.

headline.main: BRADLEY CONCEDES HE'S GOT ALL EGGS IN MARCH 7 BASKET

docs.abstract: Former Senator Bill Bradley says flatly that he must win Democratic presidential primaries in several states on next big primary day on March 7 and must sell his agenda more powerfully to hard-core Democrats who streamed to Vice Pres Al Gore in Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary; expresses optimism about prospects for presidential nomination, but seems to concede, along with many Democrats, that race will be effectively over if he fails to emerge from March 7 with significant victories; prominent Democrats say Bradley's losses to Gore in Iowa and New Hampshire makes him far less potent contender than Gore, even though Bradley has money to match Gore in future contests; say Republican candidate Sen John McCain's surge over Gov George W Bush in New Hampshire has complicated Bradley's game plan since while Gore is drawing far more of loyal Democrats than Bradley, McCain is taking far larger share of independents and even intriguing some Democrats who may have backed Bradley (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying too many poor women lack access to breakthrough cancer treatments, President Clinton proposed today that states provide full Medicaid benefits to uninsured women who have breast cancer or cervical cancer. In his weekly radio address, the president said his budget proposal for fiscal 2001 set aside $220 million over five years so states could provide Medicaid coverage to uninsured women who are screened through the National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program and discover they have cancer.

headline.main: Clinton Seeks Aid for Women With Cancer

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton says too many poor women lack access to breakthrough cancer treatments; proposes that states provide full Medicaid benefits to uninsured women who have breast cancer or cervical cancer; says his budget proposal for fiscal 2001 sets aside $220 million over five years so states can provide Medicaid coverage to uninsured women who are screened through National Breast and Cervical Cancer Early Detection Program and discover they have cancer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Moving to steady a candidacy that she acknowledges has stirred concern about her political skills and spirit, Hillary Rodham Clinton says she is now prepared to press an aggressive campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the race for United States Senate, drawing distinctions on issues ranging from school vouchers to tax cuts, and arguing that Senate Republicans ''don't need any more votes'' in Washington. In her first extended interview devoted to her Senate candidacy, timed to coincide with her official announcement this afternoon, Mrs. Clinton took pains to present herself as a moderate Democrat. She went out of her way to note her support for the death penalty, welfare restrictions and a balanced budget.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Vows Fight on Issues and Image

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in first extended interview devoted to her Senate candidacy, says she is prepared to press aggressive campaign against Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani, drawing distinctions on wide range of issues; takes pains to present herself as moderate Democrat, noting her support for death penalty, welfare restrictions and balanced budget; says she will use her formal announcement speech to try to offer voters education about her personal background and professional accomplishments; blames conservative attacks for distorting public's view of her; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The intense battle among George W. Bush, John McCain, Al Gore and Bill Bradley for their parties' nominations has brought with it a striking thematic development. Despite their claimed ideological differences, the candidates are often quite close together in endorsing the need for improvements in education, health care and programs for the poor. Although Mr. Bush's tax cut proposal has an anti-government tinge to it, the candidates have defined an unacknowledged consensus over the desirability of a strong federal role in critical areas of domestic policy. Clearly, they are responding to signals from the voters about governing from what the pollster Mark Penn and others call the ''vital center.'' In a remarkably short time, the campaign's hottest star, Mr. McCain, has transformed himself from a single-issue candidate backing campaign finance reform to one with a series of proposals that alter some traditional G.O.P. positions. The most distinctive of these is his proposal to scale back on tax cuts and spend a large chunk of the projected budget surplus on Social Security, Medicare, various domestic programs and paying down the federal debt. Like every major candidate, he also favors the right to sue health maintenance organizations. Mr. McCain also wants prescription drug subsidies for the elderly and health care for poor children. The senator calls himself a Reagan conservative, but these are not policies associated with conservatism for the last 20 years.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds presidential candidates George W Bush, John McCain, Al Gore and Bill Bradley, despite their claimed ideological differences, have defined unacknowledged consensus over desirability of strong federal role in key domestic areas; sees them responding to signals from voters (M)h

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW YORK City obstetrician lost his license last week for carving his initials into the belly of a patient after he delivered her first child. The incident and the actions taken afterward have raised ethical questions about the responsibilities of American hospitals and legal ones about when doctors should face criminal prosecution, and not just malpractice suits.
docs.abstract: Handling of incident in which obstetrician, Dr Allan Zarkin, cut his initials into patient's belly after delivering baby raises ethical questions about responsibilities of hospitals and legal ones about when doctors should face criminal prosecution; Beth Israel Medical Center forced Zarkin to resign, but did not call police; most medical injury cases have gone to court as civil malpractice suits rather than criminal or intentionally wrongful injury cases; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WAYNE GOEHRING ran a successful cabinet refinishing business until about two years ago, when he began noticing strange sensations in his feet and hands. Multiple sclerosis was soon diagnosed. Now he struggles both physically and financially. He has had to disband the Kitchen Tune-Up franchise he opened in 1989 in Bismarck, N.D., liquidate all financial assets and file for personal bankruptcy. His wife, Cindy, has gone to work in a bingo hall because the $923 in monthly disability checks he receives from Social Security isn't enough to meet everyday expenses.

headline.main: The Big Risk That Few Workers Protect Against

docs.abstract: Advice for workers on buying comprehensive disability insurance to replace part of income in event of debilitating illness or injury; graph of disabling chronic conditions; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If Congress passes a special law to grant American citizenship to Elian Gonzalez (news article, Jan. 29), lawmakers will have to devise a way to replace the health care benefits he would thereby lose. Then they might turn their thoughts to extending national health benefits to the other 44 million American citizens who don't have any. TYLER RESCH Shaftsbury, Vt., Jan. 29, 2000

headline.main: Where Elian Gonzalez Can Grieve and Heal

docs.abstract: Letter from Tyler Resch says if Congress passes special law to grant American citizenship to Elian Gonzalez, he would lose health care benefits he had in Cuba; hopes American lawmakers will consider extending national health benefits to Elian and 44 million American citizens who do not have any (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Solidly in the Republican camp, Tom Miller rattled off the issues most important to him: taxes, the economy, health care. Abortion was nowhere near the top of the list.

headline.main: For Many, Abortion Is Lost in the Crowd of Issues

docs.abstract: For all the passionate debate over abortion among presidential candidates, interviews with more than 50 voters in Michigan, Illinois and Wisconsin find that it is rare voter who sees abortion issue as pivotal; taxes, the economy and health care are seen more important issues; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Solidly in the Republican camp, Tom Miller rattled off the issues most important to him: taxes, the economy, health care.    Abortion was nowhere near the top of the list.
